Selected Answer: A
The answer is the letter A, it calls the methods o by default and when instantiating, it also calls the methods of the parent class automatically always first, printing on the screen "Vehicle Bus".

The answer is B because P2 has inherited 
from P1 therefore any object of P2 can be called P1's instance.

Selected Answer: C
The answer is the letter C. There is not much to say, he is accessing the variable "greet" of the variable "t" which is an object of type "app", and this variable "greet" is Welcome!

There is a problem with the question, i think the answer is AC.
because (s1 == "Moon") && (s2.equals("Moon")) evaluate to true.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C, as although it looks like the OraString is overriding the equals method. But its actually just a method as the Objects equals method required Object as the parameter. Hence the second statement of if((s1 == "Moon") && (s2.equals("Moon"))) evaluates to false.

Selected Answer: C
The answer is the letter C, even though I try the same content, strings are different if they are parsed as "==" or something like that because they are not primitive types. The correct way to compare the contents of String and different objects is equals and its variegated. Right in the first if of false (B) and in the second if of true (C), printing BC.

Selected Answer: B

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B because it gives a compilation error, the variable "foo" is an instance and an addition is being made inside a static method and cannot, for it to receive the addition, it needs to be static to be used in any method from class.
